messages: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:14): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: can't remember what I wanted to ask you at the time. in the mean time, I came up with another question: since value for input@type=email can now be a list, what are you inclined to change the name of the datatype to?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:14): emaillist?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:15): seems like addresslist or addresses would also work
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:15): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I suppose that's what has to happen
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:15): as far as your naming conventions
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:15): looks at spec
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:16): http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#valid-e-mail-address-list
0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (19:16): Title: HTML 5 (at www.whatwg.org)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:16): sigh. comma-separation
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:16): yeah, I just noticed that too
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:17): so *list name and list {} not going to work
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:17): wonder why Hixie made it comma-separated
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:18): to keep my conventions, the name for the datatype should be email-list
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:19): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: to be a subset of RFC2822 (or whatever the spec that replaced it is numbered)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:21): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: huh? I can't see how RFC 2822 is relevant to this (whether the addresses should be space-separated or comma-separated)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:22): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I guess I meant to the pattern name
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:22): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I mean re: being comma-seperated

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:22): Hixie: regarding the new definition for the content model if <noscript>: is the contorted way of speccing it equivalent to behaving as if the noscript tag tokens were thrown away and then doing normal validation?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:22): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: .multiple
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:23): yeah

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:23): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: RFC 2822 defines comma-separated 'address-list', so I guess the point is that HTML5's address lists should be a subset of address-list
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:23): input.email.elem.multiple
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:23): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:24): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: I see. but not clear to me why we'd want to follow that. HTML5 doesn't allow spaces within the addresses
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:24): so a space-separated list would work
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:24): I think
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:26): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: What benefit would spaces have?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:26): perhaps I should invoke a nested parser in the fragment mode for noscript content but merge the parse events going into the validator
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:27): on a related note, CRLF shows yet another aspect of painfulness when it comes to speculative parsing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:27): because now the tokenizer mustn'toverwrite CRLF in place, since doing so would confuse a retokenization
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:28): I wonder if whoever came up with CRLF realized how big a problem it would be for posterity
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:30): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: easier to express in Relax NG
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:30): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I doubt they did; if they did I doubt they would have used it
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:33): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: That sounds like a pretty weak reason
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:33): since it'll affect a total of about three people out of all of humanity
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:34): That's a whole 0%!
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:35): HTML5 hasn't been designed to be nicely expressible in Relax NG at all, so this seems like an odd place to start
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:37): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: I can't think of other form-input values that take a comma-separated list
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:37): I don't think there are any
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:37): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Are there any that take any sort of list?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:37): yeah
